body: Around Town Museums and Sites American Museum of Natural History: 'Adventures in Superstring Theory' (Wednesday) Dr. S. James Gates Jr., a theoretical physicist who specializes in the mathematical study of string theory, will present a lecture at 7 p.m. Cocktails and refreshments are available; must be 21 or older. Central Park West and 79th
title: Spare Times

body: The show did not pander, fans said. It did not condescend. It showed Brooklyn, they insisted, for what it was -- a place, apparently, with unlicensed private detective work, armies of baby strollers and a bearded superhero whose most salient superpower, acquired after a below-the-belt run-in with the third rail of a subway, cannot be described in a
title: Gathering to Mourn the End of a Show That Celebrated Brooklyn

body: A day after former State Senator Carl Kruger tearfully pleaded guilty to corruption charges, the campaigning to replace him began on Wednesday, with Republicans hoping for a rare victory in New York City and Democrats eager to hold the seat. The state's top elected Republican, Dean G. Skelos of Long Island, the Senate majority leader, and dozens of
title: G.O.P. Is Hopeful as Race to Replace Senator Takes Shape

body: -As many as 60,000 of the votes cast in New York State elections last year were voided because people unintentionally cast their ballots for more than one candidate, according to a study being released this week. The excess-voting was highest in predominantly black and Hispanic neighborhoods, including two Bronx election districts where 40 percent
title: CITY ROOM; Study Says Thousands Erred Using New Voting Machines

body: TOM NISHIOKA twirled his wife, Alexandra Bloom, up and down the aisles of the Park Slope United Methodist Church on a recent Saturday afternoon in Brooklyn. As Dr. Bloom danced, the skirt of her strawberry red silk dress fluttered, and her cheeks glowed. She and her husband were there to renew their vows after eight years of a marriage that has
title: After the Years' Ups and Downs, Beginning Again

body: THE girls are so little that some still have round toddler bellies. But their faces are grave and focused during ballet lessons in the storied Vaganova tradition, imported to Brooklyn, along with most of the teachers, from Russia. At the Brighton Ballet Theater School of Russian Ballet, most of the 400 students are children and grandchildren of
title: Russian Ballet, Brooklyn Flavor

body: In the hallways and classrooms of Public School 225 in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, Carolina Martinez is something of a celebrity. Students can be heard vying for her attention -- ''Ms. Carolina! Ms. Carolina!'' -- and often greet her with hugs. Ms. Martinez, 32, is the parent outreach coordinator in the afterschool program at the Shorefront YM-YWHA
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; A Giver to the Community Learns to Accept Its Help

body: ''Who Are You New York?: The Songs of Rufus Wainwright,'' presented at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center on Thursday night, was not just an evening for this singer and songwriter's ardent fans to savor his music, which was performed sensitively by four young singers in the first half and inimitably by Mr. Wainwright at the piano after
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; City Opera Begins a Season That Is Set on Many Stages

body: When Olga and Alexander Vartsaba won the green card lottery and moved from Russia to the United States in 2002, they believed their luck had finally changed. What they never expected was to be living nine years later in an apartment in Coney Island, Brooklyn, with no furniture -- not even beds for their three young children. The Vartsabas have had
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Giving Their Children a Place to Lay Their Heads

body: Updated, 4:58 p.m. | Five construction workers were rescued from a five-story apartment building under construction in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, that collapsed on Tuesday afternoon. One worker was in critical condition, the Fire Department said. There were no workers missing. The building, at 2929 Brighton Fifth Street, near Neptune Avenue, fell
title: CITY ROOM; Worker Dies After Being Rescued From Building Collapse in Brooklyn

body: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE 45TH ANNUAL CMA AWARDS Brad Paisley, the Country Music Association's entertainer of the year, and Carrie Underwood, a nominee for best female vocalist, return as hosts of this ceremony, broadcast live from the Bridgestone Arena in Nashville. They will also sing their billboard-topping duet, ''Remind Me.'' Mr. Paisley, Vince Gill
title: What's On Today

body: Millennium Theater Shostakovich's tense music often evokes scurrying footsteps and paranoid shadows, but he also composed a charming score for a cartoon called ''The Silly Little Mouse,'' which the Brooklyn Philharmonic, conducted by Alan Pierson, performed during its season-opening concert in Brighton Beach on Thursday evening. That cartoon and
title: MUSIC IN REVIEW; Brooklyn Philharmonic

body: SCHOLA CANTORUM DE VENEZUELA Alice Tully Hall In its search for transcendence, Lincoln Center's White Light Festival has turned its gaze on several cultures, antique and modern, familiar and exotic. The music that the young, colorfully attired Schola Cantorum de Venezuela sang on Thursday evening touched on all those categories. The choir devoted
title: Music in Review

body: Classical Full performances of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. Opera - 'Anna Bolena' (Friday) Replacing the soprano Anna Netrebko in the daunting title role of this great and overlooked Donizetti work, Angela Meade sings with clarity and accuracy but also caution and coolness. The conducting of Marco Armiliato has gained more
title: The Listings

body: Only one in four students who enter high school in New York City are ready for college after four years, and less than half enroll, according to the A-through-F high school report cards released on Monday. Those numbers, included for the first time in the report cards, confirmed what the state suggested several months ago: the city still has a long
title: College Readiness Lacking, Reports Show

body: When an orchestra wants to play outside it usually ends up in a park, a pastoral setting for picnicking and music that is familiar and not too demanding: Bernstein's ''West Side Story'' Suite, say, or Mozart's ''Jupiter'' Symphony. The audience is generally as white as the wine. That was what made the first preview of the rejuvenated Brooklyn
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Rap in and of Brooklyn, With the Rumble of the Subway Trains

body: IT'S not as if Alan Pierson were hunting for a new job. A lean, sharp and energetic 37-year-old conductor, Mr. Pierson has made an enviable name for himself over the last decade as the artistic director of Alarm Will Sound, a vital, omnivorous 20-member chamber ensemble formed in 2001 by graduate students at the Eastman School of Music in
title: In Brooklyn, A New Leader Who Knows No Boundaries

body: IN 2006, when the Brooklyn Book Festival was in its first year, a panel discussion focused on how Brooklyn had shaped the writing of Jonathan Lethem, Paula Fox and Emily Barton. Pete Hamill and Jennifer Egan, both of Brooklyn, talked about their literary inspirations. Dramatic readings from the work of legendary Brooklyn writers were staged in a
title: Brooklyn Becomes Book Country Again

body: Ana Ramirez, 35, of Coney Island swung her metal detector over the sand just off the Coney Island Boardwalk in the shadow of the Wonder Wheel ride. -''People say that storms sweep a lot of sand away, so it's a good time to look for things on the beach,'' Ms. Ramirez said as she walked on the beach a few days after Tropical Storm Irene lashed the
title: For Beachcombers, The Tropical Storm Whipped Up Hopes

body: Russians are a gossipy bunch. In Soviet times the conspiratorial kitchen whisper -- over a glass of tea or a bottle of vodka -- was sometimes the only way to share information. Even now Chekhovian monologues, complete with meaningful sighs, spill forth in the confines of the sauna; ''Have you heard?'' is the greeting over a cigarette. So on Friday,
title: Reality Show Ricochets Through Brighton Beach

body: INTERNATIONAL ATTACK IS LATEST TO JOLT AFGHAN PROVINCE A group of suicide bombers blew their way into the governor's compound in Parwan Province in Afghanistan. In the three-hour firefight that followed, the attackers killed 22 people -- 6 of them police officers, the rest government staff members and civilian visitors. PAGE A4 CHINA CLOSES PLANT
title: Inside The Times

body: If the Soviet authorities had wanted to torture Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn beyond endurance, they would have forced him to watch ''Russian Dolls.'' And if wives want to scare the pants back on their errant husbands, they will show them ''Russian Dolls.'' To traditional, or let's say puritanical, Russians, a certain part of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, is
title: TELEVISION REVIEW; Left the Volga, Kept the Vulgar

author: Alina Simone, a singer, is the author of the essay collection ''You Must Go and Win.''
body: A Russian acquaintance of mine who grew up in Brooklyn told me that her father microwaved his orange juice. Her grandmother also used to heat ice cream in a saucepan on the stove. She remembers once asking her grandmother why it was even called ''ice'' cream, when by all rights it should be called warm or hot cream. ''Things have all kinds of crazy
title: TOWNIES; Do Russians Hate Ice?

body: The Brooklyn Philharmonic has announced its first season under a new music director, Alan Pierson: a slate of grab-bag community concerts with a strong popular-music inflection. The organization will offer a series of concerts in three neighborhoods -- Brighton Beach, Bedford-Stuyvesant and downtown Brooklyn -- to be played in theaters, at a
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Brooklyn Philharmonic Announces Season

body: M & I International Food breaks all the rules of American retailing. It doesn't have a catchy name. Its sales clerks don't immediately smile at customers or make small talk. And yet this supermarket and cafe on Brighton Beach Avenue in Brooklyn has inspired fierce loyalty from regulars -- most of whom seemed, on a sunny Sunday afternoon, to be as
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | BRIGHTON BEACH; Tasty Knishes, And Service With a Scowl

body: Delicacies from across the former Soviet Union are available in this shop in the predominantly Russian-speaking neighborhood of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.

body: Alex Steinweiss, an art director and graphic designer who brought custom artwork to record album covers and invented the first packaging for long-playing records, died on Sunday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 94. His death was confirmed by his son, Leslie. The record cover was a blank slate in 1939, when Mr. Steinweiss was hired to design advertisements
title: Alex Steinweiss, Who Made Album Covers Artful, Dies at 94

body: The man caught on the wiretap urged his immigrant client to fabricate a tragic past if he wanted asylum in the United States. To say that he was a victim of political repression in Albania. Or police brutality. Or even a blood feud. ''Maybe you had to leave because someone threatened to kill you,'' the man suggested. ''Because of something that
title: Asylum Ploys Play Off News To Open Door

body: Catskill, N.Y. THE journey of 120 miles begins with a single stroke, but the Chinese philosopher Lao Tzu never swam in the mighty Hudson. David Barra peered over the edge of a pontoon boat drifting north in the steady current flowing past the Rip Van Winkle Bridge here. His friend, Janet Harris, had jumped in to swim south. Her arms slid deep into
title: Seven Days And 120 Miles To Go

body: Q.An F.Y.I. item published on June 26, ''The Hotel Next Door,'' talked about fighting illegal short-term rentals through the city's Buildings Department and its Web site. title: F.Y.I.; More on Illegal Hotels

body: The Coney Island Boardwalk, opened in 1923, has inspired songs (The Drifters' ''Under the Boardwalk''), plays (Herb Gardner's ''The Goodbye People'') and fiction (Delmore Schwartz's ''In Dreams Begin Responsibilities''). Now, it is inspiring a question of Talmudic complexity: Can a boardwalk be called a boardwalk if it is not made of boards? Last
title: A Fight Over Keeping Boards in the Boardwalk

body: Entering the phrase ''reality dating shows'' into Google delivers a grim cultural history of the millennium's first decade. Has anything worthwhile been produced in any medium at all during the last 10 or so years? It is easy to forget when perusing a chronology that more or less begins with ''Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?'' and takes us
title: TELEVISION REVIEW; They Might Find Romance If They Avoid the Crocodiles

author: Lucy Ferriss's sixth novel, ''The Lost Daughter,'' will be published in February.
body: VACLAV & LENA By Haley Tanner 292 pp. The Dial Press. $25 Magic and magical thinking are the means by which the innocent can acquire power. This accounts for the appeal not only of the Harry Potter books but of adult-minded novels like Michael Chabon's ''Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay.'' Now Haley Tanner's first novel, ''Vaclav & Lena,''
title: Brighton Beach Magic

body: NEW YORKERS went to bed on Sunday and woke up on Monday buzzing -- and posting -- about the Tonys (also #tonyawards), where a strong slate of nominees, a much-talked about and much-nominated ''Book of Mormon'' and a disarming host -- that would be Neil Patrick Harris or NPH, as he is also known on Twitter -- restored the theater awards to a place
title: TRENDING N.Y.C.

body: A 19-year-old man was arrested in connection with the shootings last week on the Brighton Beach Boardwalk that left a girl dead and four men wounded, the authorities said Monday. Witness accounts helped lead detectives to the man, Iloune Driver, who was arrested about 9 a.m. Monday. He was arraigned on a charge of second-degree murder in Brooklyn
title: Police Arrest 19-Year-Old In Shootings At Boardwalk

body: Beachgoers in bathing suits and the patter of residents speaking Russian: Brighton Beach on a hazy Friday in June. But there were also packs of police officers, some in uniform and some in plain clothes; a pile of discarded crime scene tape; several patrol cars; and a mobile watch tower, obvious clues that something had happened there.
title: A Family Mourns as Bathers Return to a Beach

body: One person was killed and four others injured during a wild shooting on a packed Boardwalk in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, on Thursday afternoon, the police said. The shooting unfolded on a day when a mini-heat wave and a school holiday sent hordes of people to Coney Island and Brighton Beach, which were teeming with beachgoers -- many of them
title: Gunfire on a Boardwalk Kills One and Injures Four

body: IF the last couple of years are any indication, about 50,000 fans will show up at Belmont Park on Saturday to watch the running of the 143rd Belmont Stakes, the premier race on the New York State calendar. Belmont can handle a crowd twice the size, but it's an off year. No horse will run for the Triple Crown, since Animal Kingdom, the long-shot
title: Belmont Awaits Its Annual Return to Glory

author: Susannah Meadows writes the Newly Released column for The Times.
body: VACLAV & LENA By Haley Tanner 292 pages. The Dial Press. $25. There comes a point in almost every relationship when you discuss the future. Where is this heading? Do you want to get married? Do you want to get married? Vaclav and Lena have had this talk. It has gone well. Vaclav and Lena are 10. In Haley Tanner's wonderful and wrenching debut
title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; Young Russians in Brooklyn Find Love, the Wonder Wheel and Then Life

body: A free concert series in Brooklyn promoted by Marty Markowitz, the borough president, will move to a new performance space in Coney Island after a dispute with neighbors around the park where the concerts took place for 20 summers. Mr. Markowitz announced on Monday that the Seaside Summer Concert Series, held since 1991 at Asser Levy/Seaside Park,
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Seaside Summer Concerts Moving to Coney Island

body: ON a sunny day, with a cool breeze blowing off the water and people sitting at sidewalk tables sipping tea from small glasses, Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, could almost be in Istanbul -- or even in the Ukrainian port city of Odessa. Which may explain why so many Turkish and Ukrainian immigrants have made themselves at home among the
title: LIVING IN | SHEEPSHEAD BAY, BROOKLYN; Calm and Clamor, in Equal Measure

body: In Coney Island, he was known as ''the rabbi.'' With his thick white beard and pointy mustache, muscled biceps and faded white tank top, Abraham Novitsky, better known as Rabbi Abraham Abraham, did not have a traditional congregation. His synagogue, people who knew him liked to say, was the beach, where he had been a fixture on the Boardwalk and on
title: Coney Island Bids Farewell To 'the Rabbi' of the Beach

title: Spare Times

body: Young Farmers ''The Greenhorns,'' a 50-minute documentary about young farmers, will be shown today at 7 p.m. at Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue (Second Street), followed by a panel discussion. Tickets, $45, will benefit the National Young Farmers' Coalition; brownpapertickets.com, event 172440. A Feast, but Not for Long LTO, or Limited
title: Calendar

body: The human voice is a symphony, Arthur Lessac said, if only one knows what to listen for. With their sustained, purring timbre, the consonants ''m'' and ''n'' are stringed instruments. Luxuriant ''w'' and ''zh'' are woodwinds, raucous ''r'' a trombone. ''L'' is a mellow saxophone; ''ch'' a clash of cymbals; and the small explosions ''p,'' ''b'' and
title: Arthur Lessac, Holistic Vocal Coach, Is Dead at 101

body: SOMETIMES getting a child into a child's pose is harder than it sounds. Natalie Wardan, 2, spent little if any time on her yoga mat in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, one recent Friday in a class for children and mothers. Instead, Natalie ran laps around the room and squirmed underneath a mesh gate to get to the studio's entryway. Unfazed, her mother, Melissa
title: STRETCH; Can Teetering Toddlers Find Balance in Yoga?

body: Alina Simone is a folk-pop singer who lives in Brooklyn. Alina Bronsky is a fast-rising European novelist who lives near Frankfurt, Germany. Both are young, both are of Soviet extraction, and both have books coming out this spring. As far as coincidences go, that's not a stunning one, but it further underscores recent artistic contributions from
title: REMIX: BOOKS; Hammer and Tickle

body: LET'S get this out of the way: The golf courses in New York City will never be confused with Pebble Beach, Bethpage Black or any of America's great public courses. If you want a four-and-a-half-hour round, meticulously manicured greens or even an unfailingly polite playing partner, consider going elsewhere. But if you appreciate the idea of hauling
title: Fairways Where Golf Becomes The City Game

body: Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, may move one of his long-running concert series this summer because of opposition over the shows' noise and a proposal for a huge new amphitheater there. Seaside Summer Concerts, one of two free series presented by Mr. Markowitz, has been held at Asser Levy/Seaside Park, on the border of Coney Island
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Brooklyn Concert Series May Be Moving

body: HELLER--Norman Norman Heller, July 3, 1927-March 25, 2011, corporate executive, gifted photographer, impassioned jazz enthusiast, beautiful swimmer, enthusiastic sailor and skier, exemplary husband, father, and grandfather, died of pneumonia, age 83. title: Paid Notice: Deaths HELLER, NORMAN NORMAN HELLER

body: For much of her life, Rita Margules knew practically nothing about how her mother, Clara Lemlich Shavelson, had changed the world a century ago. ''It never came up,'' Ms. Margules said. ''My mother was not one to say, 'Oh, you know what I did as a young girl?' '' This week, as the centennial of the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire is commemorated,
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; One Woman Who Changed The Rules

body: A tiny round table for two, tucked into a corner of the Via Della Pace restaurant on East Seventh Street, was missing its usual occupant. But Danilo Gallinari could not stop in for a last bite of Gorgonzola gnocchi or veal scaloppine on Tuesday because he was already on his way out of town, sent packing after two and a half seasons by the Knicks in
title: A Knick Is Traded, And Italians Are Desolate

body: FROM his bar stool, Askold Verbitsky yelled a message to his fellow Ukrainian-Americans on a recent evening: ''There's no more club anymore! We're finished!'' Then he shook his head mournfully and turned back to the bar. Though other members of the Ukrainian Sports Club wore less visible despair, most turned glum at the mention of the group's
title: A Ukrainian Club Faces the Last Call

body: As a lifelong resident of Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, Gary Atlas would always enjoy seeing the robust old Russians marching up the beach, dripping and content after a frigid dip in the wintry ocean. So in September 2007, while unemployed and tending to his mother, Enid, who was dying of emphysema, Mr. Atlas sought relief from depression by running on
title: SWEAT; Workout for a World of Grief
